Tragically, Jesse Brown died on that mountain, leaving behind a wife and two year old. But today he is remembered as a hero.
 
Said his friend Roland Christensen, "A man's greatness is not measured by the years he's had here but the way he lived his life." #BlackHistoryMonth

In an act of immense courage, flightmate Tom Hudner intentionally crash landed his own plane to get to his fellow pilot.
 
"If it wasn't Jesse down there, I don't know if I'd have taken the chance I did," he said. "Jesse would have done the same thing."
https://www.cnn.com/2016/05/27/us/brown-hudner-devotion-korean-war/index.html

Brown became the Navy's first Black pilot. Then, on 4 December 1950, Brown was part of a search and destroy mission in Korea when his plane was damaged. He crashed, pinned beneath his aircraft in sub-zero weather. His flightmates assumed he had been killed, then saw him waving.

One trainer, Roland Christensen, befriended the lone Black recruit and volunteered to teach him. They remained friends long after.
 
"I'm trying to get accepted into this place here," Brown wrote in one letter to Christensen after a transfer. "I guess that I shall, finally."
He tried to join the school's aviation program, but was denied. Then, he learned of an available Navy program, and enlisted. He wanted to fly.

Following in the footsteps of his childhood hero, Olympic gold medalist Jesse Owens, he attended Ohio State University, paying his way with jobs as a waiter, janitor, store clerk, dry cleaner, and boxcar loader, working until midnight but maintaining top grades.

His father took him to an air show at age six. As a paperboy, he read in the newspaper about pioneering Black aviators. He wrote to the White House to ask that Black Americans be allowed to fly. He'd look up from working in fields and say, "I'm going to fly one of those one day."

‚ÄúAlways courageous,‚Äù U.S. Navy pilot Jesse LeRoy Brown was the U.S. Navy's first Black pilot, and the first Black naval officer killed in the Korean War. His heroism in service to our country earned him the Distinguished Flying Cross. #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FK1j20QWUAQeJpz.jpg
